items.title: Nicolas Sarkozy sentenced to jail for campaign finance scandal
items.standfirst: A Paris court on Thursday found former French President Nicolas Sarkozy guilty of criminal association for attempting to use Libya to finance his campaign illegally, The Associated Press reported.
items.content: A Paris court on Thursday found former French President Nicolas Sarkozy guilty of criminal association for attempting to use Libya to finance his campaign illegally, The Associated Press reported.

items.title: Ex-French President Sarkozy sentenced to 5 years in prison for criminal conspiracy
items.standfirst: A Paris court has sentenced former French President Nicolas Sarkozy to five years in prison for criminal conspiracy.
items.content: A Paris court has sentenced former French President Nicolas Sarkozy to five years in prison for criminal conspiracy.

items.title: Sarkozy‚Äôs spectacular downfall marks turning point in France‚Äôs struggle against graft
items.standfirst: Experts say political legacy of former president convicted of criminal conspiracy now appears impossible to rebuildNicolas Sarkozy given five-year prison sentence after Libya trialWhen a Paris court handed Nicolas Sarkozy a five-year prison sentence on Thursday ‚Äì for criminal conspiracy over a scheme to get election campaign funds from the regime of the late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi ‚Äì it was a historic moment for modern France.The rightwing Sarkozy, who served as president between 2007 and 2012, was known in office not just for his hard line on immigration and national identity but for championing harsher sentencing for delinquents. He is now expected to enter jail within a matter of months. Continue reading...
items.content: Experts say political legacy of former president convicted of criminal conspiracy now appears impossible to rebuildNicolas Sarkozy given five-year prison sentence after Libya trialWhen a Paris court handed Nicolas Sarkozy a five-year prison sentence on Thursday ‚Äì for criminal conspiracy over a scheme to get election campaign funds from the regime of the late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi ‚Äì it was a historic moment for modern France.The rightwing Sarkozy, who served as president between 2007 and 2012, was known in office not just for his hard line on immigration and national identity but for championing harsher sentencing for delinquents. He is now expected to enter jail within a matter of months. Continue reading...

items.title: Sarkozy says he will ‚Äòsleep in jail but with head held high‚Äô after conviction
items.standfirst: Former French president receives five-year prison sentence for criminal conspiracy over pact with Gaddafi regimeThe former French president Nicolas Sarkozy said he would ‚Äúsleep in jail but with my head held high‚Äù after receiving a five-year prison sentence for criminal conspiracy ‚Äì the first time a former head of state has been sent to prison in modern French history.The verdict and sentencing followed a trial in which he and his aides were accused of making a corruption pact with the regime of the late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi to receive funding for the 2007 French presidential election campaign. Continue reading...
items.content: Former French president receives five-year prison sentence for criminal conspiracy over pact with Gaddafi regimeThe former French president Nicolas Sarkozy said he would ‚Äúsleep in jail but with my head held high‚Äù after receiving a five-year prison sentence for criminal conspiracy ‚Äì the first time a former head of state has been sent to prison in modern French history.The verdict and sentencing followed a trial in which he and his aides were accused of making a corruption pact with the regime of the late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi to receive funding for the 2007 French presidential election campaign. Continue reading...

items.title: Sarkozy says he will ‚Äòsleep in prison, but with head held high‚Äô following guilty verdict in Libya trial ‚Äì as it happened
items.standfirst: Sarkozy found guilty of criminal conspiracy for receiving millions of euros from late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi and will spend time in custody even if he appealsHere is a bit more on that from Reuters:Sarkozy, who has always denied the charges, was accused of making a deal with Gaddafi in 2005, when he was France‚Äôs interior minister, to obtain campaign financing in exchange for supporting the then-isolated Libyan government on the international stage.‚Ä¶ Continue reading...
items.content: Sarkozy found guilty of criminal conspiracy for receiving millions of euros from late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi and will spend time in custody even if he appealsHere is a bit more on that from Reuters:Sarkozy, who has always denied the charges, was accused of making a deal with Gaddafi in 2005, when he was France‚Äôs interior minister, to obtain campaign financing in exchange for supporting the then-isolated Libyan government on the international stage.‚Ä¶ Continue reading...

items.title: Nicolas Sarkozy found guilty of criminal conspiracy: What we know
items.standfirst: Sarkozy has been handed a five-year prison sentence after trial over finances from late Libyan leader Gaddafi.
items.content: Sarkozy has been handed a five-year prison sentence after trial over finances from late Libyan leader Gaddafi.

items.title: From power to prison: The stunning downfall of France's former president Nicolas Sarkozy
items.standfirst: Nicolas Sarkozy, once a dynamic and controversial leader who promised to transform France, has been sentenced to five years in prison for criminal conspiracy tied to illegal campaign funding from Libya. This marks a stunning fall for Sarkozy, who has faced numerous legal battles since leaving office in 2012 and now becomes the first French head of state to face jail time in decades.
items.content: Nicolas Sarkozy, once a dynamic and controversial leader who promised to transform France, has been sentenced to five years in prison for criminal conspiracy tied to illegal campaign funding from Libya. This marks a stunning fall for Sarkozy, who has faced numerous legal battles since leaving office in 2012 and now becomes the first French head of state to face jail time in decades.

items.title: French ex-president Sarkozy says he is innocent in Libya trial, will appeal conviction
items.standfirst: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy said on Thursday he was innocent and that he would appeal a court's decision to sentence him to five years in prison. A judge found Sarkozy guilty of criminal conspiracy but acquitted him on other corruption charges in a trial over efforts to procure funds for his 2007 presidential bid from Libya during the rule of Muammar Gaddafi. FRANCE 24's journalists have the analysis.
items.content: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy said on Thursday he was innocent and that he would appeal a court's decision to sentence him to five years in prison. A judge found Sarkozy guilty of criminal conspiracy but acquitted him on other corruption charges in a trial over efforts to procure funds for his 2007 presidential bid from Libya during the rule of Muammar Gaddafi. FRANCE 24's journalists have the analysis.

items.title: French ex-President Nicolas Sarkozy convicted of criminal conspiracy
items.standfirst: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy has been sentenced to prison for criminal conspiracy, over a plot linked to former Libyan dictator Muammar Qaddafi.
items.content: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy has been sentenced to prison for criminal conspiracy, over a plot linked to former Libyan dictator Muammar Qaddafi.

items.title: Former French president Sarkozy given five-year sentence after Libya case
items.standfirst: Nicolas Sarkozy, president from 2007-12, was found guilty of criminal conspiracy but cleared of other charges.
items.content: Nicolas Sarkozy, president from 2007-12, was found guilty of criminal conspiracy but cleared of other charges.

items.title: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy has been sentenced to five years in prison
items.standfirst: For the first time in French history, a former president has been sentenced to prison. Nicolas Sarkozy was handed a five-year sentence by a Paris court for criminal association tied to alleged Libyan financing of his 2007 campaign. Though acquitted of the most explosive corruption charges, the ruling marks a seismic shift in France's political and judicial landscape. Joining us for in-depth analysis, Delano D'Souza welcomes Philippe Moreau Chevrolet, Professor of Political Communications and Public Affairs at Sciences Po and President of MCBG Conseil.
items.content: For the first time in French history, a former president has been sentenced to prison. Nicolas Sarkozy was handed a five-year sentence by a Paris court for criminal association tied to alleged Libyan financing of his 2007 campaign. Though acquitted of the most explosive corruption charges, the ruling marks a seismic shift in France's political and judicial landscape. Joining us for in-depth analysis, Delano D'Souza welcomes Philippe Moreau Chevrolet, Professor of Political Communications and Public Affairs at Sciences Po and President of MCBG Conseil.

items.title: Nicolas Sarkozy guilty: A look back at the Libyan campaign funding case
items.standfirst: On September 25, 2025, former French President Nicolas Sarkozy was sentenced to five years in prison after being found guilty of criminal conspiracy related to alleged illegal campaign financing from the regime of Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi during his 2007 presidential campaign. Here's a look back at the Libyan campaign funding affair.
items.content: On September 25, 2025, former French President Nicolas Sarkozy was sentenced to five years in prison after being found guilty of criminal conspiracy related to alleged illegal campaign financing from the regime of Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi during his 2007 presidential campaign. Here's a look back at the Libyan campaign funding affair.

items.title: French ex-president Nicolas Sarkozy sentenced to 5 years in prison
items.standfirst: A Paris court sentenced former French president Nicolas Sarkozy to five years in prison for criminal conspiracy over allegations that Libya‚Äôs late leader Muammar Gaddafi funded his 2007 presidential campaign. He will be taken into custody at a later date, and the order remains in force even if he appeals, as FRANCE 24's Claire Paccalin explains from the court.
items.content: A Paris court sentenced former French president Nicolas Sarkozy to five years in prison for criminal conspiracy over allegations that Libya‚Äôs late leader Muammar Gaddafi funded his 2007 presidential campaign. He will be taken into custody at a later date, and the order remains in force even if he appeals, as FRANCE 24's Claire Paccalin explains from the court.

The Seattle company will pay US$1-billion‚Ä¶

The company will be required to pay a $1 billion civil penalty and provide $1.5 billion‚Ä¶

items.title: Amazon to pay $2.5bn to settle FTC lawsuit over Prime ‚Äòsubscription traps‚Äô
items.standfirst: US regulator said company enrolled millions of customers into service without consent and made it difficult to cancelAmazon has agreed to pay $2.5bn in fines and redress to Prime subscribers to settle a lawsuit by the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC), which accused the retail giant of signing users up for the service without their consent and making it difficult to cancel.In a statement, the FTC said $1.5bn of the total will go into a fund to repay eligible subscribers, on top of a $1bn civil penalty. Continue reading...
items.content: US regulator said company enrolled millions of customers into service without consent and made it difficult to cancelAmazon has agreed to pay $2.5bn in fines and redress to Prime subscribers to settle a lawsuit by the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC), which accused the retail giant of signing users up for the service without their consent and making it difficult to cancel.In a statement, the FTC said $1.5bn of the total will go into a fund to repay eligible subscribers, on top of a $1bn civil penalty. items.title: Amazon to pay $2.5 billion to settle U.S. lawsuit that it 'tricked' people into Prime
items.standfirst: Federal regulators say Amazon has agreed to pay a historic sum to resolve their allegations that its web designs manipulated millions of people into paying for Prime subscriptions, which were also purposefully hard to cancel. Affected shoppers are slated to receive payouts.
items.content: Federal regulators say Amazon has agreed to pay a historic sum to resolve their allegations that its web designs manipulated millions of people into paying for Prime subscriptions, which were also purposefully hard to cancel. Affected shoppers are slated to receive payouts.(Image credit: UCG/UCG/Universal Images Group via G)

items.title: Amazon, FTC Reach $2.5 Billion Deal in Prime Subscription Case

items.content: Amazon.com Inc. agreed to pay $2.5 billion in penalties and refunds and change its process for how to cancel its Prime subscription to settle a lawsuit by the US Federal Trade Commission.

Cisco said Wednesday that the vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-20352, was present in all supported versions of Cisco IOS and Cisco IOS XE, the‚Ä¶

items.title: As many as 2 million Cisco devices affected by actively exploited 0-day
items.standfirst: Search shows 2 million vulnerable Cisco SNMP interfaces exposed to the Internet.
items.content: As many as 2 million Cisco devices are susceptible to an actively exploited zero-day that can remotely crash or execute code on vulnerable systems. Cisco said Wednesday that the vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-20352, was present in all supported versions of Cisco IOS and Cisco IOS XE, the operating system that powers a wide variety of the company‚Äôs networking devices. The vulnerability can be exploited by low-privileged users to create a denial-of-service attack or by higher-privileged users to execute code that runs with unfettered root privileges. It carries a severity rating of 7.7 out of a possible 10. Exposing SNMP to the Internet? Yep ‚ÄúThe Cisco Product Security Incident Response Team (PSIRT) became aware of successful exploitation of this vulnerability in the wild after local Administrator credentials were compromised,‚Äù Wednesday‚Äôs advisory stated. ‚ÄúCisco strongly recommends that customers upgrade to a fixed software release to remediate this vulnerability.‚ÄùRead full article Comments
